title: Paul's Defense Before Agrippa
shortSummary: In Acts 26, the Apostle Paul presents a powerful defense of his faith before King Agrippa, recounting his former life as a persecutor of Christians, his dramatic conversion on the road to Damascus, and his mission to proclaim Christ. This chapter highlights the transformative power of Christ and the boldness required to witness for Him even in the face of opposition.
timeline: c. AD 57 - Paul's Imprisonment and Defense in Caesarea

keyCharacters.name: Paul
keyCharacters.description: The Apostle and former Pharisee who defends his faith and ministry before King Agrippa, sharing his conversion and mission.

keyCharacters.name: King Agrippa
keyCharacters.description: A Jewish king familiar with Jewish customs who listens to Paul's defense and expresses near belief in Christ.

keyCharacters.name: Festus
keyCharacters.description: The Roman governor who interrupts Paul, questioning his sanity, but also facilitates the hearing before Agrippa.

keyCharacters.name: Bernice
keyCharacters.description: Sister of King Agrippa, present during Paul's defense.

definitions.definition: A member of a strict Jewish sect known for strict adherence to the Law of Moses and traditions.
Set apart as holy; made pure through faith in Christ.
An idiom meaning to resist or oppose authority or correction in a futile way.
A sincere turning away from sin and turning toward God, accompanied by a change in behavior.

outline.heading: Paul's Permission to Speak and Introduction
outline.description: Paul is granted permission by King Agrippa to defend himself and begins by acknowledging Agrippa's knowledge of Jewish customs, setting a respectful tone for his testimony.

outline.heading: Paul's Former Life and Persecution of Christians
outline.description: Paul recounts his strict Pharisaic background and his zealous persecution of Christians, demonstrating his dramatic transformation from enemy to servant of Christ.

outline.heading: Paul's Conversion on the Road to Damascus
outline.description: Paul describes the heavenly light and the voice of Jesus confronting him, commissioning him to be a witness to both Jews and Gentiles, emphasizing divine calling and mission.

outline.heading: Paul's Ministry and Defense of the Gospel
outline.description: Paul explains his obedience to the heavenly vision, his preaching of repentance, and the fulfillment of prophecy concerning Christ's suffering and resurrection.

outline.heading: Reactions and Agrippa's Response
outline.description: Festus accuses Paul of madness, but Paul asserts his sobriety and truthfulness; Agrippa expresses that Paul nearly persuades him to become a Christian, and the leaders conclude Paul is not deserving of death.

application: Be ready to give a clear and respectful defense of your faith, knowing that God can use your testimony to impact others.
Recognize that God can transform even the most unlikely individuals and use them for His purposes.
Respond obediently to God's calling, even when it leads to hardship or opposition.
Encourage others toward repentance and faith by living consistently and boldly for Christ.

keyVerses.text: To open their eyes, and to turn them from darkness to light, and from the power of Satan unto God, that they may receive forgiveness of sins, and inheritance among them which are sanctified by faith that is in me.
keyVerses.significance: This verse encapsulates Paul's mission and the gospel's power to bring spiritual transformation and salvation.

keyVerses.text: Then Agrippa said unto Paul, Almost thou persuadest me to be a Christian.
keyVerses.significance: Shows the compelling nature of Paul's testimony and the personal challenge of responding to the gospel.

keyVerses.text: But shewed first unto them of Damascus, and at Jerusalem, and throughout all the coasts of Judaea, and then to the Gentiles, that they should repent and turn to God, and do works meet for repentance.
keyVerses.significance: Highlights the call to repentance and the inclusive scope of the gospel message.
